Expectation1: Review and analyze legal documents and contracts
Situation1: A merger contract contains clauses that could expose the client to immediate financial liability if not examined promptly.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: A flash-flood warning triggers building alarms as water rises along the block.
Story: I sat at my desk, the merger contract spread out before me, red pen poised to catch any clause that might endanger my client. The clock ticked past midnight, and I knew every minute mattered—if I missed something, my client could face devastating financial loss. My phone buzzed with a flash-flood warning, and moments later, the building alarms blared. I looked out the window; water was already pooling in the street, creeping toward the entrance. As a lawyer, I was expected to keep my focus, to scrutinize every word of the contract before dawn. But as a citizen, I was supposed to help—check on neighbors, follow evacuation orders, maybe even assist the elderly couple down the hall. My heart pounded as I weighed the contract in my hands, the sirens echoing in my ears, torn between the duty to my client and the responsibility to my community.
